==German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|de|Wir}} {{q|pluralis majestatis}} * {{l|de|-wa}}, {{l|de|wa}} {{q|rare, colloquial}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|de|gmh|wir}}, from {{inh|de|goh|wir}}, from {{inh|de|gem-pro|*wÄ«z}}, {{m|gem-pro|*wiz}}, from {{inh|de|ine-pro|*wÃ©y-}}, plural of {{m|ine-pro|*Ã©Çµhâ‚‚}}. Compare {{cog|nds|wi}}, {{cog|nl|wij}}, {{cog|en|we}}, {{cog|da|vi}}, {{cog|is|vÃ©r}}, {{cog|got|ğ…ğŒ´ğŒ¹ğƒ}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{qualifier|standard}} {{IPA|de|/viËÉÌ¯/}} :* {{audio|de|De-wir.ogg|audio}} :* {{rhymes|de|iËÉÌ¯}} * {{qualifier|colloquially in unstressed position}} {{IPA|de|/vÉ/|/mÉ/}} ===Pronoun=== {{head|de|pronoun|cat2=personal pronouns}} # [[we]] ====Inflection==== {{de-decl-personal pronouns}} * The genitive case ''unser'' is used more and more rarely in modern German. * While the genitive of a personal pronoun does express ownership, it must not be confused with a possessive pronoun. While possessive pronouns such as {{l|de|unser}} are put in front of the noun they relate to and follow the inflection rules of adjectives, the genitive form of a personal pronoun has only one form, which is not further inflected. Additionally, personal pronouns in the genitive can be put after the word they relate to. ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} ---- ==Middle High German== ===Etymology=== From {{inh|gmh|goh|wir}}, from {{inh|gmh|gem-pro|*wÄ«z}}, {{m|gem-pro|*wiz}}. ===Pronoun=== {{head|gmh|pronoun}} # {{l|en|we}}: {{nominative plural of|gmh|ich}} ====Descendants==== * {{desc|cim|bar}} * {{desc|de|wir}} ---- ==Old English== ===Alternative forms=== * {{alter|ang|Æ¿Ä«r}} ===Etymology=== From {{inh|ang|gem-pro|*wÄ«raz}}.
